job_title: Front Desk Associate in Milledgeville, GA
pros: Great work environment Friendly co-workers
cons: Not much room for growth

pros: Georgia College (GC) is a great place to work. But it all depends on your department. My department was great fun to work with and very flexible. Pay is good when you consider cost of living in Baldwin County. For example, 46,000 here would equate to roughly 76,000 in Metro Atlanta. Benefits are good including health, dental, vision, TRS (401k / pension plan), AD&D, and much more. The best benefit by far is the Tuition Assistance Program or TAP. This allows any full-time employee who has worked more than 6 months at the institution to take college courses for free. GC is a smaller campus, so if you're willing to learn new things and help others, you'll find the entire campus faculty and staff are happy to teach you.
cons: Hiring from within isn't terribly common, so the position you are hired for is often the one you are stuck with. This isn't the private sector, so yearly raises or cost of living adjustments aren't common either. The hours can be a little weird including late nights and weekends, but that comes with the territory of working in video and for a university. Undergrad students don't work on an 8-5 schedule after all. Also public sector jobs are NOT for the impatient. Hiring can take months, so be warned and patient. But once you get your foot in the door and hired, you're set.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Macon, GA
pros: money time off coworkers students
cons: none none none none none

pros:
- They really work with you and your class schedule, as well as any second jobs.
- If you are a student, the work demand is much, much less than would be asked of you in a non-university job.
- All of the administrators and professors that I came into contact were professional, but courteous and often remarkably friendly.
cons:
- Not enough hours. You will probably never get enough hours to get more than "beer money" really.
- Low-pay, outside help replacement. Some of the things you might do would be better suited for someone with more experience, but you are a cheaper alternative to get the same job done.
- You're an extra. In a lot of positions, you're sort of like an extra set of hands. The federal government could be paying you (in a work-study) in which case, you are like free labor that might not have much put on your plate.
- Some jobs must be reapplied for every semester, and your position is not guaranteed.

review_title: Aquatic Supervisor position at the Georgia College Wellness & Recreation Center
pros: You work with fellow college students who, in my experience, have all become friends of mine. The work is not that hard and the patrons are very nice. At this facility the center is only open to students and patrons 18 years of age and older. This means no little kids going crazy that could be found at neighborhood pools.
cons: The work hours are low. Some weeks I would only work 4 or 7 hours. However as a regular Lifeguard you can easily pick up dropped shifts.

review_title: Great students, great environment, frustrating leadership
pros: Georgia College has excellent students. They are top-notch and being able to be a part of the environment and mentor them is a great opportunity. The university is beautiful, has a great spirit and is in a neat, small southern town.
cons: There is a group of middle management and vice presidents who have been around too long who have their own best interests in mind above the university's. They need to move on. This is particularly true in Enrollment Management and Advancement. There is an incredible amount of turnover in these two divisions. Someone needs to find out why so many people don't want to work for these leaders.

review_title: Great environment with opportunities to be creative
pros: Depending on your department you will have opportunities to be creative and innovative to achieve the mission of the university.  As a relatively small campus, staff have the ability to get involved in committees and councils to influence the direction of the university.
cons: Like any institution of higher education, politics can get in the way of progress.  That is what keeps me from giving 5 stars.  On a departmental level, this is not an issue (at least in my area).  But on a whole, politics and who is married or related to whom can cause issues.

review_title: I'm an undergraduate student so working as a stockroom assistant gave me a lot of basic skills not taught in class.
pros: The people are nice there, and they understand how busy you can get with school work. They are always willing to help you out when you don't find something. The fact that you are working in a place full of chemicals, being a Science major in school, really helps you with your Laboratory courses.
cons: Payment as a student is relatively low compared to other schools. The size of the school can make certain people bored to get bored at their jobs.

job_title: Village Office Assistant in Milledgeville, GA
pros: As a student worker, I really enjoy my position as the work isn't too stressful. Really, the only busy time in our office is when the beginning of the semester comes around and everyone needs to come pick up books. This is a great position if you want something that allows you to spend time studying for classes, or anything else.
cons: As I said above, only con is that it can be extremely hectic at the beginning of the semester but once everything winds down you get into a good groove and can mange many problems.

job_title: Risk Management Specialist in Milledgeville, GA
pros: Great people and the students that you work with are respectable. Every day you meet new students and to be able to help college aged men and women is fulfilling.
cons: The pay isn't great for student workers and there is some disconnect between the different offices. Nothing that can't be fixed with some integration.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Fellow in Milledgeville, GA
pros: This was an assistantship so it waived my out-of-state tuition costs and gave me a small stipend. It also gave me teaching experience. There is a lot of freedom to be creative and to do what you want as a teacher.
cons: There was very little training or guidance given on how to teach the classes although one could get some one-on-one help quite easily if desired. Milledgeville is not a very appealing place to live because of the limited restaurants and cultural offerings.

pros: Good managers and you get lots of training and space to ask questions. You work with friendly students and staff. Flexible hours
cons: Lowish pay, hours can be changed or cut without much notice. Store gets very slow at times

pros: If you can get a position that doesn't consume all of your time, you can obtain a Master's degree for FREE! It's the reason that most people take a position here. Work for two years, grab a free Master's degree and move on to something better. Also the health, dental retirement benefits are excellent. Essentially, you're working for the University System of Georgia (Meaning you're a State employee).
cons: The Office of Admissions is horrendous! They work their Admission Counselors 100 hrs + during travel season, and they give you hell when you try to make your job easier. Be prepared to pay your bills AND THEIRS. They won't give you a credit card to pay for all the hotel expenses you're expected to pay. They will reimburse you though...About a week to 2 weeks later. Have some spending money on tap. However, that will probably be a little difficult seeing as how they pay 5k to 10k less than other Universities. Also be prepared to do your job plus 50 others. Someone quits EVERY month. I wish I was joking, but for the 2 years I was there, someone quit every month like clock work. Management is extremely bias, so don't expect to move up unless they like you. There's way too much politics in the Enrollment Mgmt Dept. of Georgia College. They usually hire Alumni, but really think twice about taking a position there if you are- Once you see how the administrators at this school really are, you may be ashamed that you got your degree from there. All in all, it's not worth it. Hold out for a better position. Working for ANY Public University in the state of Georgia can get you a free Masters or PhD.

review_title: Not a bad place to be

cons: Student body more interested in partying than studying. Diversity of student population is low. NOT enough pay, at all. No guarantee of summer income.
